description.narrative: The food security situation in South Sudan continues to deteriorate since the outbreak of fighting in December 2013. The humanitarian crisis have spiralled with more than three million people fleeing the conflict and seeking refuge in neighbouring countries and others as Internally Displaced Persons. According to the recent September integrated food security phase classification (IPC) findings in the Republic of South Sudan analysis, an anticipated earlier than normal start of the lean season will result in an estimated 5.2 million people will face worse acute food insecurity between January and March 2019. However, there is greatest concern in counties where harvests are likely to be poor and possible returns from within and outside of the country may cause further pressure on already scarce resources. As a result, extreme levels of acute food insecurity are expected to persist in many areas. This calls for immediate and unhindered provision of humanitarian assistance (South Sudan IPC, 2018). Caritas South Sudan will coordinate with its stakeholders such CIMO in country, government authorities represented by the Relief and rehabilitation commission, beneficiaries in the proposed sectors: food security and livelihoods, non-food items (NFI), peace and reconciliation. The Confederation will be regularly updated on the implementation progress the Baobab and Caritas Africa website. The newly signed revitalized peace agreement by the political antagonizing parties in South Sudan will result in to massive return of people from both outside and within the country to their areas of origin. However, the proposed three-year appeal plans to serve 123,727 individuals for a total budget of 5,631,523 Euros in lifesaving and community resilience.
